content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I've tried it out in python, it's a fun puzzle, though it's not an easy one. I'd say it's a medium puzzle (not a hard one in my opinion)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Combines string manipulation and branching logic, nice puzzle.

Nice puzzle, I like it.
The last 2 tests are a bit of a trap though, having '-' in the name of the switches was a low blow :)
I feel like this is higher difficulty than easy.

I'd expect the zero-switch case (validator "Tow lights") to be a test too (not only a validator) especially for the easy category.
This is just a remark. I don't know if others agree. 
I'll approve this nice puzzle once other problems are fixed anyway.

The default code for Clojure throws an exception, but other than that I don't think there are any glaring issues with this puzzle.

Regarding the goal statement, there are a few things I might consider changing. First, having  "...all switches in series must be on..." instead of "... switches in series must be all on..." on line 5 of the goal statement. Second, I might add something about how circuits can have multiple sets of switches in series or in parallel. When I attempted to solve the puzzle I initially assumed that there would only be one set of switches in series and one set of parallel switches and had to make a few tweaks to my solution when I reached the later test cases, but I could attribute that misunderstanding to me not reading the goal statement closely enough. 

Overall a very nice puzzle. Once the Clojure default code issue is fixed and the goal statement is polished up a little more you can count on my vote for approval,

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is good. More boolean parsing type puzzles are definitely needed. Very fresh idea
For your circuit ascii art, I would suggest that you close the circuit, e.g. add a line from the right end to the left of the power supply.

Nice problem, a few typos here and there.

* Switches may participate to multiple circuits >>> "in" multiple circuits.
(I don't think this sentence is necessary to begin with though.)

* name of the [[EQUIPEMENT]] and wiring description >> extra "E" in EQUIPEMENT

Also one clarification issue: using [[IDENTIFIER]] was a little confusing to me. I think just [[SWITCH]] is fine. If you want to change it, then in the statement you should rephrase "Switch identifiers are unique" to "Each [[SWITCH]] has a unique name." Also in the input, "the switch [[IDENTIFIER]] Tom manipulated" can be "the [[SWITCH]] that Tom toggled." I think toggled is a better word in either case.
OK, rephrased as proposed and removed the part about switches participating in multiple circuits as the example clearly highlights this.

I see your point but I did not want to make it too complex.

I could replace the power supply line with something like

`[POWER SUPPLY]==+------------------------------------+`

The purpose of the long "------------------------------------" cable is to close the circuit. The "==" caracters could symbolise the fact that the power supply has two  terminals (actually as many as necessary).

Hello, thanks for your comment, I rephrased accordingly for the first point, but for the second point, I agree this can be attributed to assumptions that further test cases will clear up ;-)

For the Clojure part, I don't know how to fix it as it seems related to the stub generator. The Clojure code that gets generated does not consume the "end of line" character when reading integer into C or A. As a result, the next "read-line" returns an empty string and inputs get mixed up.

Below is a sample to illustrate this. If you remove the comments before "(read-line)", the code works. I don't see how I can fix this.

UPDATE: I opened a ticket for this one, see https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/clojure-stub-generator/186064

(ns Solution
  (:gen-class))

; Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
; the standard input according to the problem statement.

(defn output [msg] (println msg) (flush))
(defn debug [msg] (binding [*out* *err*] (println msg) (flush)))

(defn -main [& args]
  (let [C (read)]
    ; (read-line)
    (loop [i C]
      (when (> i 0)
        (let [WIRING (read-line)]
        (debug (str "WIRING: " WIRING))
        (recur (dec i)))))
    (let [A (read)]
      ; (read-line)
      (loop [i A]
        (when (> i 0)
          (let [SWITCH (read-line)]
          (debug (str "SWITCH: " SWITCH))
          (recur (dec i)))))
      (loop [i C]
        (when (> i 0)
          
          ; (debug "Debug messages...")
          
          ; Write answer to stdout
          (output "ANSWER")
      (recur (dec i)))))))
I agree this one is tricky because the "zero actions" use case is not covered by public tests, but I find it adds a little salt if one does not read carefully the puzzle constraints :)

Hello, you might be right, the right level should be set to "medium" difficulty.

I don't think this ranks as difficult. Does anyone else have a feeling about this?

Tbh the main difficulty was to parse the strings to extract the tokens you need.
The branching logic is fairly simple. I would keep it in the easy category.
the issue with Clojure defaut code has been fixed. Thanks for pointing it out. Cheers
Great, thanks!

Well, I guess the first thing anyone learns in school about circuits is that they have to be closed. So I think it would be easier to understand if there is a line going around and going from the left into the power supply.
Power supply now integrated into the diagram, to clearly close the circuit.
